title: PHPend()Function

metadata.description: Learn about PHPend()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example Output the value of the current and the last element in an array: "; echo end($people); ?> Definition and Usage The end() function moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the last element in the array. Related methods: current() - returns the value of the current element in an array - moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the prev() - moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the reset() - moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array each() - returns the current element key and value, and moves the internal pointer forward Syntax end( array ) Parameter Values Parameter Description array Required. Specifies the array to use Technical Details Return Value: Returns the value of the last element in the array on success, or FALSE if the array is empty PHP Version: 4+ More Examples Example A demonstration of all related methods: "; // The current element is Peter echo echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?> ★ +1

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:
"; // The current element is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Joe is Peter echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Cleveland is Glenn echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?>

practice_exercises.solution:
"; // The current element is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Joe is Peter echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Cleveland is Glenn echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?>

summary: This tutorial covers PHPend()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use PHPend()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of PHPend()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
